subject: Re: [EVP-ITC] File uploading rules-ATTENTION JON
author: Rj
full_text:
--0-934530323-1241991355=:55334
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=iso-8859-1
Content-Transfer-Encoding: quoted-printable

A file's content, it's integrity, is simply the bytes (and their bits) in t=
he file.=A0 If the file's content integrity is changed, that is, by definit=
ion, changing the bytes.=A0 If the bytes in there are not changed, then tha=
t integrity has not changed.

It is possible to mess with other things abou=
t a file (like its name, its suffix, or its ownership) but this does not ef=
fect the contents, and so would not affect that integrity, or the sound of =
the file (assuming you could read it at all after changing the ownership, o=
r the suffix, etc).

When you do your tests, if you cannot do a bit level c=
omparison, I would recommend at least checking the file sizes.=A0 If they a=
re identical, there is a very high probability that the content has not cha=
nged.

Admittedly I do not=A0know much about =

bit-level comparisons, what they can or can't show so I will have to leave=
 that 
to you. I have doubts because I worry once a file's integrity has be=
en messed 
with, I wonder that even though the bits match, maybe that doesn=
't mean they are 
the same quality as the original. I really don't know tho=
ugh what is possible or 
impossible when it comes to this area.
=A0
"It is =
probably possible to set up an email compression scheme that does do 
lossy=
 audio compression.=A0 My tests show my setup does not.=A0 If you'd 
like m=
e to help test your setup, we can do that too. From what I see, lossy 
comp=
ression from an attachment would be very unusual."
=A0
The problem I have i=
s that not just from 
Jon, but I have heard it from other people, and a pro=
fessional and they 
all=A0said that loss is possible. From 
all that, my co=
nclusion was that maybe in some cases loss was 
possible.
=A0
However, your=
 arguments do put doubt back 
into my mind, which pisses me off, because I =
had originally argued feverishly 
for no loss, then I heard different from =
different sources and decided to do 
what=A0I=A0thought was the right thing=
 by contacting a third party 
professional. So after all that, I decided I =
was licked and had to eat 
crow.
=A0
Now I am back at square one, from the =
other 
side LOL!!! Computer people have been wrong in the past.
=A0
=A0
"It=
 is 
probably possible to set up an email compression scheme that does do l=
ossy audio 
compression.=A0 My tests show my setup does not.=A0 If you'd li=
ke me to 
help test your setup, we can do that too. From what I see, lossy =
compression 
from an attachment would be very unusual."
=A0
I have not test=
ed it from my computer, as I 
haven't had any problems with loss. I would r=
eally like to have Jon work with us 
on this, because he was the original p=
erson who told me I was 
wrong.
=A0
But I will test it from my side. I will=
 send 
a wav file to one of my other addresses. Then I will download and co=
mpare. If I 
think I hear a difference, then maybe I can have you do a bit-=
level comparison 
on the files.
=A0
Either way, I am going to get to the bo=
ttom 
of this.
=A0
=A0
=A0

=
    
      Yes you can tell loss of quality by a bit-level 
        compari=
son.=A0 An audio file is just a file of bytes, that is later 
        inter=
preted by an audio player.=A0 Two files with the exact same 
        conten=
ts, whether they are audio or image or a dababase or an exe, are 
        i=
ndistinguishable from each other.=A0 That is, if I copied the 
        cont=
ents of one to a new file, and the contents of the other to a new 
        =
file, and asked you which file each came from, there would be no way to 
  =
      tell.=A0 Even the audio player could not tell.=A0 The data is 
      =
  identical, and so the sound (or the picture, etc) would be 
        ident=
ical.

Yes I did listen to the results, but that is not the 
        best t=
est (they sounded identical, but that is a subjective 
        opinion).=A0=
 The real test is compring the contents.=A0 Identical 
        contents mea=
ns indentical data, means identical audio.

It is 
        probably possibl=
e to set up an email compression scheme that does do 
        lossy audio c=
ompression.=A0 My tests show my setup does not.=A0 If 
        you'd like m=
e to help test your setup, we can do that too. From what I 
        see, lo=
ssy compression from an attachment would be very 
        unusual.

                I can't vouch for your compute=
r or servers, but 
                  I just did some tests, and sent a 2.1M=
B wav file from MSN to 
                  Yahoo and back, once allowing com=
pression, and once turning it 
                  off.=A0=A0 I was able to v=
erify that one was compressed 
                  and one was not, by checki=
ng the sizes when they arrived at 
                  Yahoo. Once they came =
back to MSN, I then did a bit-level 
                  comparison of the or=
iginal, and the ones sent around 
                  email.=A0 They were all=
 identical, which indicates lossless 
                  compression.

If yo=
u have a file you'd like me to test 
                  for you, let me know=

                  for how your ser=
ver's work, without testing them 
                  yourself.

                    For executables, you may 
                    be r=
ight. However, for wav files, the compression during 
                    e=
mail is not loss less. 
                    =A0
                    I used =
to think as you 
                    do, in that the emailed attachment=A0o=
f a wav file would 
                    not loose anything. After a lengthy=
 discourse with another 
                    member here, I learned that I =
was wrong. The reason 
                    why=A0I did not realize it in th=
e first place is that 
                    when I would email a wav file, I=
 would intentionally keep it 
                    in very small segments, t=
o keep file size down. This was 
                    just for ease of trans=
fer. But because of this, I had not 
                    experienced any no=
ticeable loss.
                    =A0
                    Now it may be in=
 some 
                    cases, depending on the servers or what have you=
 that the 
                    file goes through, that the loss may be less=
 or more. But 
                    once the attachment is 
                =
    downloaded,=A0the=A0quality=A0has been found to be 
                   =
 less then the original wav.
                    =A0
                    Ag=
ain though you can 
                    only really tell when the=A0wav fil=
e is 
                    large.
                    =A0

=

                      
                      
                      
     =
                   
                        
                          The =
kind of compression that occurs 
                            during an emai=
l attachment is "lossless": it 
                            compress the fi=
le cleverly without losing 
                            information.=A0 For=
 example, if I had a program 
                            in some .exe file=
s, and I sent it over email, it 
                            could compress=
 it.=A0 But if it lost even one 
                            bit, the resul=
ting exe file would not execute again 
                            after it=
 was uncompressed on the other 
                            side.

This kin=
d of compression does things 
                            like looking for =
common patterns in the file, and 
                            replacing the=
m with a token.=A0 A rough example 
                            would be if=
 it found "Howdy Neighbor" in a file 20 
                            times,=
 it could replace all the occurances with say 
                            =
$HN1.=A0 And also write a little dictionary in 
                           =
 there someplace that says "$HN1=3DHowdy 
                            Neigh=
bor".

When the file gets to its 
                            destination i=
t can be uncompressed, and all 
                            occurences of $=
HN1 are replaced with "Howdy 
                            Neighbor".=A0 So =
it was compressed (instead of 14 
                            characters ea=
ch, it only needed 4, plus the 
                            dictionary), bu=
t lost no data.

Some formats, 
                            like jpeg and m=
p3. are not lossless.=A0 Depending 
                            on the leve=
l of compression, some level of data is 
                            lost, =
and so cannot be recovered or reconstructed 
                            la=
ter.

Rick

                              Anothe=
r 
                              thing:
                              =A0
 =
                             I recently 
                              foun=
d this out. When you email a file, if it is 
                              =
not saved as a compressed format, the email 
                              =
filtering process will actually compress the file 
                        =
      automatically.
                              =A0
                    =
          So even if you 
                              have attached a wav=
. file, it will loose 
                              resolution over the em=
ail process. It will not 
                              sound exactly the s=
ame as the original wav. file. 
                              How much it d=
iffers depends on the size of the 
                              file you a=
re attaching. If it is a very=A0large 
                              file, =
it will sound much different.
                              =A0
           =
                   The only 
                              exception to thi=
s is if the wav. file is small 
                              enough that t=
he filtering process will ignore it. 
                              It has =
to be pretty small though, like under 
                              1=A0MB=
 (I am not exactly sure of the 
                              threshold).
 =
                             =A0
                              The best way=
 
                              to share files over the internet=A0if you w=
ant 
                              them as close to the original as possibl=
e is to 
                              upload them directly to a website.
 =
                             =A0

        From: 
                                Rj

   EVP-ITC@yahoogroups .com

            =
                    
Pixelization doesn't clean-up 
                       =
         the data: it replaces it.=A0 Imagine taking a 
                   =
             picture of a field of flowers, and beginning to 
             =
                   add levels or pixelization to the picture.=A0 
         =
                       Soon, you would not be able to tell there were 
    =
                            flowers there at all.=A0 You would see a lot 
 =
                               of colored blocks.

Or in the other 
       =
                         direction, imagine you are looking at a 
         =
                       competely randomize bunch of pixes on your 
        =
                        screen: a complete screen of truely random 
       =
                         static snow.=A0 Pixelizing this, after a 
        =
                        while, you would again start to see colored 
      =
                          blocks.

What's happening is that it is 
        =
                        processing an area of the image, taking (for 
     =
                           instance) the average value of that entire area,=
 
                                and replacing all the blocks in that area=
 with 
                                the average.=A0 In video processing,=
 this 
                                would result in a field of multi-col=
ored flowers 
                                being replaced by, for instan=
ce, a big 
                                greyish-bluish block, with no re=
semblance to 
                                flowers.=A0 In the noise exam=
ple, it maybe 
                                replace all the random pixel=
s with another big 
                                greyish-bluish block.=
=A0 If you did not know 
                                beforehand what th=
e original picture was, you 
                                couldn't tell =
whether your pixelized image was 
                                really a =
field of flowers, a chevy, the sky with 
                                cl=
ouds, or a random bunch of pixels.

It 
                                wor=
ks the same with the sound files.=A0 
                                Takin=
g something as complex as speech, and 
                                repl=
acing frequencies with their averages, loses 
                             =
   the speech the farther you go, until you head 
                         =
       strange fluctuating square waves.=A0 Doing 
                        =
        the same to random static will eventually 
                        =
        produce the same thing.=A0 And random 
                            =
    fluctuating square waves can sound a bit like 
                        =
        speech - or at least, you could have fun sharing 
                 =
               with each other what you thing they 'sound 
                =
                like'.

                                Be a bit careful of fo=
rmats like 
                                mp3 if you are doing a detailed=
 analysis of the 
                                sounds though.=A0=A0 Whil=
e some formats 
                                (like wav) can store the au=
dio very close to the 
                                way it was recorded,=
 formats like mp3 compress 
                                the file, and i=
n so doing lose some of the sonic 
                                details.=
=A0 This may not be a big deal in 
                                music, w=
here the audio is fairly clear to begin 
                                wi=
th.=A0 But with sound sources with a lot of 
                              =
  noise (like evps), this can not only obscure any 
                       =
         real sounds, but pixelize non-sounds (like white 
                =
                noise) and make them start to sound like 
                 =
               speech.

So mp3 might be good for sharing 
                 =
               the data, once you've already formed an opinion 
           =
                     based on an analysis of the wav file.=A0 But 
        =
                        mp3 is not good as a medium for analysis.=A0 
     =
                           It can lead to many false positives and 
       =
                         misinterpretations.

 <tr>
      <td valign=3D"top">Yes you can tell loss of quality by a bit-le=
vel 
        comparison.  An audio file is just a file of bytes, that =
is later 
        interpreted by an audio player.  Two files with the =
exact same 
        contents, whether they are audio or image or a dababase=
 or an exe, are 
        indistinguishable from each other.  That is, =
if I copied the 
        contents of one to a new file, and the contents of=
 the other to a new 
        file, and asked you which file each came from,=
 there would be no way to 
        tell.  Even the audio player could =
not tell.  The data is 
        identical, and so the sound (or the pi=
cture, etc) would be 
        identical.<br><br>Yes I did listen to the res=
ults, but that is not the 
        best test (they sounded identical, but t=
hat is a subjective 
        opinion).  The real test is compring the =
contents.  Identical 
        contents means indentical data, means id=
entical audio.<br><br>It is 
        probably possible to set up an email c=
ompression scheme that does do 
        lossy audio compression.  My t=
ests show my setup does not.  If 
        you'd like me to help test y=
our setup, we can do that too. From what I 
        see, lossy compression =
from an attachment would be very 
        unusual.<br><br><br>--- On <b>Sun=
, 5/10/09, April Abercrombie 
        <i><april@abercrombiegh ostresearc=
h. com></i></b>

                <td valign=3D"top">I can't vouch =

                  e=
mail.  They were all identical, which indicates lossless

                          <td valign=3D"top">The kind of com=
pression that occurs 
                            during an email attachmen=
t is "lossless": it 
                            compress the file cleverly=
 without losing 
                            information.  For example=
, if I had a program 
                            in some .exe files, and I=
 sent it over email, it 
                            could compress it.&nbs=
p; But if it lost even one 
                            bit, the resulting =
exe file would not execute again 
                            after it was =
uncompressed on the other 
                            side.<br><br>This ki=
nd of compression does things 
                            like looking for=
 common patterns in the file, and 
                            replacing th=
em with a token.  A rough example 
                            would b=
e if it found "Howdy Neighbor" in a file 20 
                            ti=
mes, it could replace all the occurances with say 
                        =
    $HN1.  And also write a little dictionary in 
                    =
        there someplace that says "$HN1=3DHowdy 
                          =
  Neighbor".<br><br>When the file gets to its 
                            =
destination it can be uncompressed, and all 
                            oc=
curences of $HN1 are replaced with "Howdy 
                            Neig=
hbor".  So it was compressed (instead of 14 
                         =
   characters each, it only needed 4, plus the 
                           =
 dictionary), but lost no data.<br><br>Some formats, 
                     =
       like jpeg and mp3. are not lossless.  Depending 
              =
              on the level of compression, some level of data is 
         =
                   lost, and so cannot be recovered or reconstructed 
     =
                       later.<br><br>Rick<br><br><br><br>--- On <b>Sun, 
  =
                          5/10/09, April Abercrombie 
                     =
       <i><april@abercrombiegh ostresearch. 
                           =
 com></i></b> wrote:<br>

 <table border=3D"0" cellpadding=3D"0" cellspacing=3D"0">

               =
                 <td valign=3D"top"><br>Pixelization doesn't clean-up 
    =
                            the data: it replaces it.  Imagine taking =
a 
                                picture of a field of flowers, and begin=
ning to 
                                add levels or pixelization to the =
picture.  
                                Soon, you would not be able=
 to tell there were 
                                flowers there at all.&=
nbsp; You would see a lot 
                                of colored block=
s.<br><br>Or in the other 
                                direction, imagi=
ne you are looking at a 
                                competely randomiz=
e bunch of pixes on your 
                                screen: a complet=
e screen of truely random 
                                static snow.&nbs=
p; Pixelizing this, after a 
                                while, you wou=
ld again start to see colored 
                                blocks.<br><=
br>What's happening is that it is 
                                processi=
ng an area of the image, taking (for 
                                insta=
nce) the average value of that entire area, 
                              =
  and replacing all the blocks in that area with 
                         =
       the average.  In video processing, this 
                      =
          would result in a field of multi-colored flowers 
               =
                 being replaced by, for instance, a big 
                  =
              greyish-bluish block, with no resemblance to 
               =
                 flowers.  In the noise example, it maybe 
           =
                     replace all the random pixels with another big 
      =
                          greyish-bluish block.  If you did not know 
=
                                beforehand what the original picture was, y=
ou 
                                couldn't tell whether your pixelized im=
age was 
                                really a field of flowers, a chevy=
, the sky with 
                                clouds, or a random bunch o=
f pixels.<br><br>It 
                                works the same with th=
e sound files.  
                                Taking something as c=
omplex as speech, and 
                                replacing frequencie=
s with their averages, loses 
                                the speech th=
e farther you go, until you head 
                                strange f=
luctuating square waves.  Doing 
                                the s=
ame to random static will eventually 
                                produ=
ce the same thing.  And random 
                                fluctu=
ating square waves can sound a bit like 
                                sp=
eech - or at least, you could have fun sharing 
                           =
     with each other what you thing they 'sound 
                          =
      like'.<br><br><br><br><br><br>--- On <b>Sun, 
                       =
         5/10/09, Misty Dawn <i><bulletbabea@ 
                         =
       yahoo.com></i></b> wrote:<br>

ockquote style=3D"border-left: 2px solid rgb(16, 16, 255);"><br>From:

I have the 
                                original for analysis. </div>
 =
                               <div> </div>
                          =
      <div>As far as pixelization of non sounds/white 
                    =
            noise whos to say that isnt being manipulated by 
             =
                   them as well LOL. Water is a form of white 
            =
                    noise. I seem to remember some experiments done 
      =
                          with blank tapes/film, no recording done 
  =
                              yet there were voices/images there. I find it=
 
                                all interesting.</div>
                  =
              <div> </div>

 thought. Ok off to work now!</div>

er=3D"0" cellpadding=3D"0" cellspacing=3D"0">
                             =
   <tbody>
                                <tr>
                           =
     <td valign=3D"top">Be a bit careful of formats like 
                 =
               mp3 if you are doing a detailed analysis of the 
           =
                     sounds though.   While some formats 
       =
                         (like wav) can store the audio very close to the 
=
                                way it was recorded, formats like mp3 compr=
ess 
                                the file, and in so doing lose some of=
 the sonic 
                                details.  This may not be =
a big deal in 
                                music, where the audio is fa=
irly clear to begin 
                                with.  But with s=
ound sources with a lot of 
                                noise (like evp=
s), this can not only obscure any 
                                real sou=
nds, but pixelize non-sounds (like white 
                                n=
oise) and make them start to sound like 
                                sp=
eech.<br><br>So mp3 might be good for sharing 
                            =
    the data, once you've already formed an opinion 
                      =
          based on an analysis of the wav file.  But 
                =
                mp3 is not good as a medium for analysis.  
          =
                      It can lead to many false positives and 
            =
                    misinterpretations.<br><br>--- On <b>Sun, 
            =
                    5/10/09, Misty Dawn <i><bulletbabea@ 
              =
                  yahoo.com></i></b> wrote:<br>
